The C program structure:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <ctype.h>

int main() {
    int N;
    scanf("%d", &N);
    double sum = 0.0;
    for (int i = 0; i < N; i++) {
        double x;
        char unit[10];
        scanf("%lf %9s", &x, unit);
        if (strcmp(unit, "JPY") == 0) {
            sum += x;
        } else {
            sum += x * 380000.0;
        }
    }

    // Now convert sum to a string as Java would output it.
    // Need to format it properly.
    // Using a buffer to hold the string.
    char buffer[100];
    // Use a format that avoids scientific notation and shows enough decimals.
    // Java's default for a double is to print as many digits as needed without scientific notation.
    // So using "%.17g" to get enough precision.
    sprintf(buffer, "%.17g", sum);

    // Now process the string as per the second program's logic.
    int len = strlen(buffer);
    char ch = 0;
    for (int i = len - 1; i >= 0; i--) {
        if (buffer[i] != ' ' && buffer[i] != '?') {
            ch = tolower(buffer[i]);
            break;
        }
    }
    if (ch == 'a' || ch == 'e' || ch == 'i' || ch == 'o' || ch == 'u' || ch == 'y') {
        printf("YES");
    } else {
        printf("NO");
    }
    return 0;
}
